workingTogether.title: What working together looks like
workingTogether.intro: Every conversation is co-created. We protect space so you decide pace, language, and depth while we bring steady reflection.

points.title: You lead, we partner
points.description: You choose the topic each time. We listen, question, and mirror patterns so decisions come from your judgement, not our agenda.

points.title: Small, realistic experiments
points.description: Sessions end with one or two actions you willingly choose—often tiny, evidence-gathering steps that fit UK life, visas, and capacity.

points.title: Ethical, confidential, calm
points.description: We follow ICF ethics, name boundaries clearly, and keep conversations grounded. No guarantees, no pressure, always with consent.

forWhom.title: Who coaching is for

labels.storiesIntro: Every client sets their own goals. These short stories are illustrations, not guarantees.

midCareer.label: Mid-career returners
scenarios: You have taken several years out for caring, health or relocation and feel unsure how to position your experience in the UK market.
You worry your skills or story look 'outdated' and want a grounded view of what is actually possible.
You want to return on your own terms rather than rushing back into the wrong role.
approach: Clarify what a sustainable next chapter looks like for you in this season of life.
Map realistic role and sector options for your situation instead of generic 'dream job' talk.
Design small, low-risk experiments so you can test ideas without burning out.
questions: If you paused the pressure to 'catch up', what would a kinder and wiser path look like?
Which parts of your past experience still feel alive and valuable now — and how might we bring them forward?

newToUK.label: Newcomers to the UK
scenarios: You are navigating UK hiring norms or workplace culture for the first time and want context without losing your own voice.
Visa timelines, family responsibilities or finances add urgency, and you need calm structure rather than hustle slogans.
You would like a space where bilingual thinking is welcomed so you can integrate experiences across cultures.
approach: Name what stability looks like in the near term so decisions feel less binary.
Translate UK expectations into language that makes sense for you and your stakeholders.
Design conversations and boundaries that honour both home-culture values and local realities.
questions: What would make the UK feel more like a place you can shape rather than just survive?
How do you want to describe your cross-border experience so it stays truthful and compelling?

graduates.label: Recent graduates and early-career explorers
scenarios: You are juggling internships, applications or portfolio building and want to choose next steps without burning bridges.
You sense pressure to pick one 'perfect' path and would like to experiment with a kinder frame.
You want support navigating family expectations, finances, or visas alongside work decisions.
approach: Define what learning, stability and joy mean for you in this stage rather than copying peers.
Co-design low-risk experiments to test options and collect evidence for future choices.
Build language to talk about your strengths and boundaries in interviews or networking without exaggeration.
questions: If you gave yourself permission to be 'in progress', what would you try first?
Which environments help you think clearly — and how can we seek more of those?

parents.label: Parents and carers re-entering work
scenarios: You are balancing care, health or community commitments and want work to fit real capacity.
You feel torn between conflicting advice from employers, family or peers and want a grounded plan.
You want to advocate for flexible arrangements or boundaries without feeling confrontational.
approach: Clarify what a workable week looks like, including rest, care and paid work.
Develop language to request support or boundaries with employers and loved ones.
Experiment with phased returns or collaborative care plans so you can test and adjust.
questions: What support structures would make this season more sustainable for everyone involved?
How can you describe your needs in a way that invites collaboration instead of guilt?

stories.title: Relocating and starting again
stories.text: A professional moved to the UK and felt their CV had been reset. Across several sessions we clarified what 'good enough for now' meant, mapped realistic options, and designed two practical experiments. They chose their next step with more calm and ownership. This is an example, not a template or guarantee.

stories.title: Returning after caring leave
stories.text: After years out for family care, a client used coaching to rebuild confidence and boundaries. Together we shaped a narrative they genuinely believed. They chose conversations and roles that matched their real capacity.

miniCases.title: Mini case snapshots
miniCases.intro: Anonymous composites that show how small, client-chosen experiments can look in practice.
miniCases.disclaimer: Outcome owned and chosen by the client.

cards.title: Returning professional in her 40s
cards.story:
Felt pressure to accept the first full-time role after relocating for her partner's job.
We mapped what financial stability actually required and rehearsed language for boundary-setting.
She chose to test a part-time contract and a local volunteering role before deciding on permanent posts.

cards.title: Newcomer product manager
cards.story:
Arrived in the UK on a partner visa and worried about starting 'too junior'.
Sessions focused on translating previous Asia-Pacific experience into UK hiring language and noticing impostor triggers.
He created a six-week networking experiment, including bilingual coffee chats and a blog post, before applying selectively.

cards.title: Graduate navigating visa deadlines
cards.story:
Held a graduate visa expiring in 8 months and felt scattered by conflicting advice.
We clarified decision criteria around sponsorship, wellbeing, and family expectations, then sized experiments.
They chose to approach three target employers with a clear ask and schedule rest days around interviews.

servicesOverview.title: Ways to work together
servicesOverview.intro: Each format begins with an intro conversation to scope goals, languages, and boundaries together.

cards.title: Transition Series · 6 sessions
cards.description: Hold structure through a specific UK life or career shift, paced so you can test ideas between conversations.

cards.title: Sustain & Balance · 8 sessions
cards.description: Longer partnerships for ongoing change, accountability, and reflective pauses across a season.

cards.title: Single deep dive · 90 minutes
cards.description: One-off session to map options, name boundaries, or prepare for a pivotal conversation.

howItWorks.title: How coaching flows
howItWorks.intro: We stay non-directive and consent-led, adjusting cadence so you can absorb insights without overwhelm.

steps.title: Intro call
steps.description: Align on expectations, scope, and boundaries, and decide together whether coaching is the right fit.

steps.title: Agreement
steps.description: Co-create coaching goals, format, fees, and safeguarding arrangements before any paid session begins.

steps.title: Coaching sessions
steps.description: 40–60 minute conversations online or in-person, led by your agenda, with reflective questions and experiments you choose.

steps.title: Review
steps.description: Harvest learning, agree next steps, and either continue, pause, or close the work with clarity.
